image.altText: A black and white image of Donald Trump, overlaid with small yellow circles, his signature, and a helicopter.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump's wealth has skyrocketed since his return to the White House nine months ago, leading to accusations that he is profiting from the presidency.

title.children: As Trump's wealth skyrockets, accusations of conflicts of interest mount

image.altText: A sign on a brick wall reads 'Western Sydney University', in the distance are some large buildings.

props.synopsis: As Western Sydney University prepares to shed hundreds of staff due to its dire finances, leaked documents reveal it is paying consultants as much as $2,850 a day.

title.children: University staff outraged as high-paid consultants work on redundancies

image.altText: Person in protective suit inside chamber with pipes and blue light.

props.synopsis: The two great technology revolutions of the modern era — artificial intelligence and renewable energy — are colliding.

title.children: A meeting in China this week may hold the key to our energy future

image.altText: A group of people sits together surrounded by Israeli flags

props.synopsis: Israel says it expects the release of hostages will begin in the coming hours, as a ceasefire with Hamas continues to hold in Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: Hostage releases expected in coming hours as Trump says 'the war is over'

image.altText: three women in military uniforms stand in front of a wall with paper cuttings and a picture of Donald trump

props.synopsis: The final 20 living Israeli hostages in Gaza are set to be released by Hamas in a matter of hours, with preparations by Israeli defence and medical authorities to receive the captives after more than two years hidden away from the world.

title.children: Israel prepares to receive hostages as deadline looms

image.altText: Board showing ASX stocks in the red.

props.synopsis: White House threats of another round of punishing tariffs on China spark a savage retreat on Wall Street. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set for sharp decline on renewed trade war fears

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ANZ to halt its $1 billion buyback
Rio Tinto on the hunt for gold in NSW

image.altText: Woman in green blazer and shoulder-length brown hair looking off to the distance, a neutral expression on her face

props.synopsis: Jelena Dokic was abused by her father for years, with no tennis success enough to stop the beatings. She reveals the complex grief of losing a parent who showed no remorse.

title.children: Jelena Dokic tried to reconcile with her dad. His response shocked her

image.altText: A giant flame roars from gas flare stack, silhouetted against the dusk sky

props.synopsis: Advocacy group Climate Integrity has accused the gas industry of using "distorted research", produced by the accounting firm EY, to influence the Australian government's Future Gas Strategy.

title.children: Regulator asked to investigate claim 'distorted research' behind government gas policy

image.altText: A woman in a grey blazer, with shoulder-length red hair, stands in front of an old wooden chest in parliament.

props.synopsis: Communications Minister Anika Wells will meet with major social media giants — such as Meta, Snapchat, Youtube and TikTok — this week to ensure they're ready for Australia's upcoming social media ban. Follow live.

title.children: Social media giants to meet with Communications Minister Anika Wells

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Burke calls for Thorpe to 'lower the temperature'
Warning on scam claims after Qantas data leaked
Don't give Thorpe 'the attention she craves': Plibersek

image.altText: A large formation of bleached staghorn coral underwater in Ningaloo.

props.synopsis: An international report from climate scientists suggests tipping points for coral reefs have been reached, putting them at risk of dieback.

title.children: Coral reefs at risk of mass dieback as global warming reaches tipping point

image.altText: the tail of a Qantas Boeing 767.

props.synopsis: The federal government is sticking to its position of not negotiating with cyber criminals, despite hackers releasing personal data from millions of Qantas customers onto the dark web and threatening to target Australia.

title.children: Government holds firm on not paying ransom to hackers

image.altText: Two hands hold a phone. The person is wearing pink and black striped fingerless gloves. The phone has a charm hanging from it.

props.synopsis: LGBTIQA+ advocates are concerned the social media ban will have a significant impact on queer youth in regional and remote areas of Australia. They say there are not enough offline, physical supports for these teens to access when the ban comes into effect.

title.children: LGBTQIA+ advocates say social media ban will 'cut off' regional queer teens

image.altText: Charlie Curnow points a finger after kicking a goal for Carlton.

props.synopsis: Carlton star Charlie Curnow is prepared to turn over every stone to ensure he can get to either Geelong or Sydney. Follow live as the AFL trade period kicks into its second week.

title.children: Curnow's reported monster sacrifice 'just to get out of Carlton'

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Curnow's reported sacrifice to force through Geelong move

image.altText: A Tomahawk missile in flight after just being launched off the deck of a US Navy ship.

props.synopsis: Kyiv and the US are openly floating the idea of providing Ukraine with long-range Tomahawk missiles, in a move Russia says would mark "a very dramatic moment".

title.children: More strikes hit Ukrainian grid as Kremlin warns against new US missiles

image.altText: A woman getting into a car with her guide dog.

props.synopsis: Sarah Maculans says she was refused rides by four Uber drivers within a week due to her guide dog, Sunny.

title.children: Independence 'chipped away' by Uber driver refusals, guide dog handler says

image.altText: Aerial picture of multiple houses under construction in new subdivision

props.synopsis: Stories about developers enacting sunset clauses and leaving would-be buyers priced out of the market are nothing new. Here's what's being done to tighten those rules.

title.children: Here's what a sunset clause is and when it can be enacted

image.altText: a kaola called gage looks at the camera

props.synopsis: Koala deaths on Appin Road are not unusual this time of year, but the fatality of rescued koala Gage is cause for more than the usual frustration and despair.

title.children: Beloved koala killed after being hailed a conservation success story

image.altText: Matt Payne wins the 2025 Bathurst 1000 as pit crew hand over railing to celebrate

props.synopsis: Wild weather and hard racing were combined with bold and colourful personalities to create a truly memorable day of Supercars racing. Here are the quick hits from the 2025 Bathurst 1000.

title.children: Trophy protest, Chaz drinks with fans, and first does not win Bathurst

image.altText: Pro-Palestinian protesters gather in Sydney's Hyde Park with flags and signs

props.synopsis: The rallies in cities and towns dubbed the Nationwide Rally for Palestine come less than a week after the second anniversary of the October 7 terrorist attack.

title.children: Thousands join pro-Palestinian rallies in towns and cities amid ceasefire

image.altText: A birds eye view of newly constructed homes and homes being built in an undeveloped area.

props.synopsis: There are growing fears that a major overhaul of planning laws promoted to fast-track housing development will bypass environmental protections and remove safeguards against corruption.

title.children: 'Deceitful' planning laws bypass environment, corruption safeguards, experts say

image.altText: Judy and Bob Dent in an older photo. He is wearing a navy suit and she is wearing a long white dress.

props.synopsis: On the verandah of their Darwin home, Judy Dent held her husband's hand as he became the first person in the world to die through legally accessible voluntary assisted dying. That world-first would not be possible in the Northern Territory today.

title.children: Judy's husband was the first person in the world to die under VAD laws

image.altText: An old, white man with grey hair and a beard look at the camera.

props.synopsis: Mount Magnet Shire deputy president Ian Black is suspended after failing to apologise for posting a defamatory notice about staff to a public noticeboard.

title.children: Councillor suspended after no apology for defamatory notice

image.altText: A female golfer at the conculsion of a stroke on a leafy course.

props.synopsis: Thai world number one Jeeno Thitikul wins the LPGA Shanghai tournament on the fifth play-off hole, with Australian superstar Minjee Lee settling for third.

title.children: Minjee Lee finishes third in epic LPGA Shanghai finale

image.altText: A large group of people wave flags and hold placards while demonstrating in front of a government building.

props.synopsis: Troops from an elite unit of the country's military are urging fellow soldiers to disobey orders and back student protesters.

title.children: Student-led coup attempt underway in Madagascar, president says

image.altText: Pink , green and purple succulents grow by native grasses with a river behind it.

props.synopsis: A sheep farmer has welcomed the restoration of an internationally significant wetland on his property outside of Hobart. The collaboration of a non-profit organisation with landowners, scientists, the Aboriginal community and governments has allowed the return of a vital ecosystem.

title.children: Abundance returns to wetland after man-made sheep pasture removed

image.altText: Three grey and white haired men dressed in grey suits with many medals on their lapels, smile near trees.

props.synopsis: Former Victoria Police officer Michael Pratt has been remembered for his bravery when he confronted three armed bank robbers in Melbourne in 1978.

title.children: 'Australia lost a true hero': George Cross recipient Michael Pratt dies

image.altText: Adelaide Lightning coach Kerryn Mitchell watches training.

props.synopsis: Former WNBL powerhouse the Adelaide Lightning was saved from the brink of collapse. But the question of how to rebuild a once-proud club from scratch is one that's been at the forefront of the minds of the new coach, chief, players and owners.

title.children: Rebuilding a fallen basketball giant takes belief and determination

image.altText: Football specatators watch a game on a foggy day

props.synopsis: In the Yarriambiack Shire, 350 kilometres from Melbourne in Victoria's rural north-west, virtually all of the towns are shrinking.

title.children: A quarter of this town's population has vanished. Experts say that could be terminal

image.altText: A woman works on a wedding dress on a mannequin with wedding dresses on hangers behind her.

props.synopsis: Chinese Australian women are paying thousands of dollars to find love on matchmaking platforms in Australia, but behind the glossy promotions lies a different reality.

title.children: 'Why marry at all?' Woman upset at matchmaking service

image.altText: Hannah Mundy celebrates Australia defeating South Africa in the third netball Test.

props.synopsis: Australia warms up for the eagerly anticipated Constellation Cup with a convincing 65-42 victory over South Africa in the third and final Test in Adelaide.

title.children: Diamonds dominate Proteas to complete series clean sweep

image.altText: A woman with long red hair stands in profile, a stern-looking woman stands behind her, facing forward

props.synopsis: First dismissed as "Gothic romance" when it was published by Daphne du Maurier in 1938, the haunting tale has evolved into a modern thriller about the expectations placed on women.

title.children: Rebecca was a novel, a Hitchcock classic, and now a thriller on stage
